author: @gee8419
text: My rent in my 4th floor walk up single bedroom in Queens went up to $2100 per month this year. 2 years ago when I moved in the apartment was $1900 per month. I am a City employee making 88k a year, after taxes, the cheapest health insurance/FSA/dental, pretax transit it's around $2100 every two weeks I take home. Curiously I looked on Street Easy for single bedroom apartments $2000 a month and under. Less than 200 apartments are available at that cost in Manhattan, Queens, Brooklyn, and the Bronx COMBINED. This is why homelessness has increased so rapidly. There are so few apartments and rent is SKYROCKETING. If rent is half my income and I make an 88k salary what hope does a single mother on minimum wage have??

replies.author: @Darth_Bateman
replies.text: ‚Ä¶..‚Äùhope‚Äù?

replies.author: @gee8419

May TMH help us find the way out!

replies.author: @ivanivanovichrasputin3098
replies.text:
Don‚Äôt forget that you have to have like 10 times your rent payment in your bank account or some stupid sheet like that. And the rent payment can only be like 30% of your monthly income. Who tf is making $7.5k+ per month in NYC other than the barely hanging on by a threat middle class?! 

5 years ago we were paying $950 for a one bedroom apartment in Brooklyn. It went up to $1,200 the same year. Now single bedroom apartments are no less than $2,100 per month. Meanwhile, wages have not increased a goddam cent. The federal minimum wage is still effing $7.25 per hour!!! Minimum wage in New York is $15/hour, and only if the business has more than like 50 employees. This state and country as a whole are a total joke.

replies.author: @TheNutCaseNetwork
replies.text: @gee8419 The south isn‚Äôt much better, you‚Äôll get more space for your money, but the average pay is less & it‚Äôs virtually impossible to get a job. Single mothers are becoming homeless. Not to mention the scams where the units charging extremely high rent either have pest infestation, or false advertising about amenities or even functionality of the unit. My water bill is $300 a month in a small 3 bedroom after living in a larger house where my water bill was $60-$100 a month. My electric bill is almost $400 a month because the windows and doors aren‚Äôt properly insulated. I moved in here and everything was broken during the summer, including the air conditioning. It was 100+ degrees inside during August in Georgia. They want us all to go on to glory, but they want black men and women to go firstüòÆ‚Äçüí®üôèüèΩü´∂üèΩüíúüß†üíØ

author: @satyasyasatyasya5746
text:
i actually think the system isn't as scared of Luigi as it pretends to be, nor as much as we like to think. Because the only thing they're really afraid of is true collective action and solidarity, but this whole thing just feeds into myths of individual action, so really, even if a few people copy him, it won't change anything.
To some extent, he's controlled opposition, and that CEO was a price that not only is the system totally cool with paying, but wasn't he replaced in like a week? They even still had the meeting he was on his way to. Like, even the system don't care about the people running it. Its wild.

Like, his targets happen to have some accuracy by coincidence, but other individualists will go target super innocent people, like the New Orleans attack.  It may encourage people to rally collectively because we love a folk hero but thats coming anyway for a lot of people.  Over a billion people at any given time on the earth in 2020 were actively fighting oppression en masse, and it still fell back.  We can certainly accomplish what is needed via mass action and as you said thats the true threat to power.  Handing out free food and getting everyone working together gets attacked even for more quickly even across privileged classes of people, than anything else.

replies.author: @dylan6386
replies.text: I‚Äôm genuinely concerned that they don‚Äôt have anything to fear at all. I‚Äôm noticing a trend where more people are asking questions like whether Luigi has a brother or if Luigi needs to strike again, rather than engaging in meaningful discussions.

replies.author: @rebelrabalmedia9524
replies.text: I'm sorry, but wouldn't all the people shouting that this is class solidarity count as collective action? Was it really the shooter or our response that really triggered the media's panic over the situation or was it what was happening on social media that made them respond in fear? Olay is absolutely right to point out that racism could have contributed to why so many people empathize a lot with the alleged shooter. [Although I would point out that Olay herself mentioned that the NYPD tried to label the shooter as a "light-skinned" person to suggest that the shooter was a minority, but even then, no one cared that he killed a CEO. That being said, I would be remiss not to point out that the video CLEARLY indicated that the shooter was white]. But at some point, when the racists are selfishly correct, we should try and use them to the best as opposed to being the used.  I'm not saying that there won't be consequences for speaking out, but there are also consequences with being complicit with the system as well. You either die now on your feet or slowly on your knees, that's all that there is in a fascist society. All I'm trying to say is that this event was not about the shooter, but how mainstream media panicked when we celebrated. This is bigger than the horrors of the mass prison industrial complex, this is about the police state as a whole.

replies.author: @jinmushui1soul
replies.text: I agree, to an extent. Most people have gained catharsis rather than motivation, yet the state will still throw everything they've got to send a clear message to anyone who might act the same. However, I don't think collective action must be centralized or that we all need to be doing the same thing at the same moment. Alternatively, our movements can be the accumulation of autonomous action in response to the accumulation of crisis. You may not kill a CEO, but you can certainly protest one, or work to create networks of lasting mutual aid. Work within your personal calculus of risk/reward and don't let other folks keep you from action because they don't agree (and on the flipside, we also need to stop policing folks who move different from us). This is the true meaning of diversity of tactics (not some lowest common denominator bs) and a "world where many worlds fit".

replies.text: What does the system have to gain by playing such a risky game? What's the prize? They want copycats & Individual action? Possibly, to you know, have reasons to militarize the Popo even more, and justify it. Still seems like a lot to risk. Yes they are very very afraid of collective conscious turning into focused class solidarity. There are better, less risky ways of snuffing out a CEO for one reason or another. And to be clear, this American capitalized system is cannibalistic, so don't be surprised how that works. What do they win though that makes all this risk worth winning? If this is controlled opposition, they're asking for a type of chaos. Which would mean instead of controlled opposition they get chaotic opposition. If that's purposeful, what are the reasons they'd want that? Or is this maybe just what it appears to be?

author: @ShimmerBodyCream
text: Good analysis. Fundamentally, I see this as a slow restructuring of Us vs Them. The oligarchy weaponizes brown people to create an Us VS Them conflict within the underclass, and this detracts from the underclass holding the ruling class responsible. If we start to see the oligarchy as the problem, it will be harder to fall for the Us VS Them Poor People edition once you know the game.

author: @animerage1862
text: when i was falling into homelessness in the city, I was looking online to find potential shelters to stay at and every forum online said something along the lines of "if you are a woman, don't even try, you will get sexually assaulted," and that was terrifying to know that my only option would be the streets then.  Thankfully I had a friend that I told my situation to that let me stay with her until I could find something, but that really opened my eyes to some of the horrors of homelessness and it hurts to hear when people talk so poorly about them.  I'm grateful everyday for the support I do have.

author: @DannyDeee
text: So... Luigi was appearantly a fan of Elon Musk and Peter Thiel. Did he view the CEO as a "rotten apple" within a system he actually approves of? Is this a case of knowing the system is rigged, but only reacting when it affects you directly?

replies.author: @aerynsunx
replies.text: @DannyDeee¬† He wasn't a fan. He liked some of their tweets, here and there. He also followed AOC on social media, was a fan of "The Lorax", and was exploring eastern and southeastern Asian philosophies. But he also liked the Unabomber's manifesto. In other words, his interests were all over the place, like a lot of young people. Better yet, like many people in general who are looking for answers in life beyond "eat, work, and die". Yeah, he sounds confused. Or maybe he's looking for real answers in a confusing, nonsensical, unjust world. But in that, he's not alone.

replies.author: @SirSpenace
replies.text:
@10:48 Steve Ahlquist wrote about this here in Rhode Island Today. Entirely relevant. (Google his name + Substack, YT won't let me link his story).

Here's a quote:
"‚ÄúDone. Easy and quick. And I had that unit re-rented in a week or two.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think much more about it. I figured my former tenant had a place to go.

I tried to justify my actions. A tenant didn‚Äôt pay his rent, so I followed the laws that allowed me to do this.

‚ÄúBut someone had died, and I have to live with the realization that my actions - my completely legal actions ‚Äì had this consequence.‚Äù"

- Former Landlord

author: @dmitrikalashnikov4754
text:
9:10 We got to see in a subsequent case a variation on a theme of how acts of violence between homeless people are reported if the alleged perpetrators have migrant backgrounds. On one hand, the victim's status as homeless can be quietly reported. On the other, the perpetrators' status as homeless can be quietly reported. Either way, the message is migrants are dangerous, and share nothing in common with us "natives." Reporting on both cases serve to obfuscate how homeless folks are marginalized. 

In Kawam's case, her status as homeless victim was quietly reported. In the case that followed, wherein a homeless guy stabbed two of five people trying to rob him, it was the the alleged robbery perpetrators' statuses of being homeless that was buried in the reporting. Both cases were reported in ways that portrayed migrants as criminals, but because everyone involved were homeless, they chose to ignore that in different ways to emphasize difference between perp and victim. In reality, less separated them than as portrayed.  

Sorry for the ramble, especially if it read as incoherent. I am just jittery and felt compelled to share what I perceive as the contrasts and parallels of these two cases.

text: Thank you for speaking on this. As a person who experienced being displaced in NY, ppl do not know how to practice empathy. The shelters are awful. Women are at risk of abuse and violence in that environment. It‚Äôs ran like a prison and ppl tell you to just go there like it‚Äôs better. I can see why they would risk being on the street. There were times I pulled all nighters and stayed up outside. It‚Äôs scary. I was fortunate that someone opened their home to me and I was able to finish my residency and find a job. author: @hopesdaughter5947
text:
üì£ I've left remarks on your old video about the Mayor. I was born and raised in Queens. I'm a former doctoral candidate for a PhD in Public Policy and Administration and a divorced Mom, unhoused with my 4 children. As soon as I went to that Bronx city facility for unhoused families and then went to and saw the shelter they were trying to send us to, also in the Bronx, I walked out. My children refused to go inside. 

I used to own 2 houses and a math tutoring business on Long Island while working in youth development in Harlem. Soooo, üôÇ we slept in a White Castles restaurant parking lot on Long Island, since it's 24 hours, and in the morning we went to the DSS building and was given much better temporary emergency housing support. 

Right now though since I've done so much previous DEI type work I believe I'm being marginalized and can't seem to get hired... and not a minimum wage job either. I was actually screened twice by the Manhattan District Attorney's Office but not moved forward and the person screening me had less experience with youth than me. I've applied to eveything you can think of, state, city, nonprofits and business. Nepotism along with racism, sexism and ageism is another big intersecting issue. ‚òÆÔ∏è

author: @habib670
text:
As to the beginning point of your video, i wonder how much we think about the lack of surveillance and monitoring of Luigi in the months before his alleged killing, either by federal or municipal authorities. Prolly little to none. 

Compare that to the hard nosed surveillance of the FBI operates on black revolutionaries and black movement politics leaders from the peak of the civil rights era to TODAY. 

And then we add to it Luigi‚Äôs upper middle class position via his upbringing and lifestyle. 

It‚Äôs with this in my mind that i wonder whether a black person would even get to that morning before some kind of municipal intervention and arrest.

replies.author: @lordfreerealestate8302
replies.text: "upper middle class" He comes from a family of millionaires. That's upperclass.

replies.author: @elleanna5869
replies.text:
Lol why would he need surveillance? He had no records of violence, never had or gave troubles, was a young adult free to detatch from his family. Unless you advocate for being vocal about US healthcare and praising British NHS as an alarming trait (this was known since  always and was reported as "Luigi had a calm, intellectual criticism about social issues, he was never angry , never upset" - so why preventing surveillance for calm expression of critical thinking against social abuse? Inception scie-fi? Former USSR? Chile in Pinochet times? )

People forcing the black vs white and rich vs poor on this have a hard time with reality (edit It would be quicker to admit you aren't interested in class conversation, it's legit - no need for further surreal arguments)

replies.author: @habib670
replies.text: @elleanna5869 the point i was trying to make: its hard for me to believe that this could have been achieved by someone of a different class and racial background as Luigi. that assumption is based on my understanding of american history of surveillance.

author: @ma-ri-ko
text: thank you for the reality check. this period in between the election and the inauguration has just felt... displaced and dissociated. i know we're all tired. i feel like the UHC murder was one of the few things to pierce that collective bubble, but it hasn't collapsed yet. it kinda feels like people are going thru the motions and plugging mangione into an internet trend cycle as an outlet for all this dissatisfaction bubbling away in the background but not many are stopping to look at the context you have provided here. thank you for bringing more attention to the circumstances of debrina kawam's murder and talking about the criminalization of homeless people, and really, whole communities, as well. been working in harm reduction and with self-governing encampments for a while and folks living on the street are way more likely to be victims of crime than perpetrators. we get a lot of attacks by people who know that the only reason police come out for homeless folks is to do sweeps.
